text:
January 20, 2017 1:26 PM ‘Join us, join us.’ McClatchy, Sacramento High students walk out of school to march against Trump Lakes, rivers and a meadow during drought years compared to January 2017 0:24 Rollover crash on Interstate 5 off-ramp at Q Street 1:23 Downed tree crushes midtown home 1:21 Friend remembers homeless man who died outside Sacramento City Hall 1:10 Sacramento woman explains why she's joining the Women's March on Washington 2:47 Grass Valley sinkhole, day-by-day, from Jan. 11-17 0:18 See the view from the bottom of Grass Valley’s massive sinkhole 2:18 FamilyTreeNow.com: Here are some tips on using it. 1:49 How much weed can you carry now that California has legalized marijuana? You might be surprised Share Video email About 100 people marched from Sacramento City College to the state Capitol Friday as part of a Sacramento protest against the inauguration of Donald Trump as president. Other groups left from three other locations to converge on the Capitol. Ryan Lillis The Sacramento Bee Protestors against the inauguration of Donald Trump as president outside C.K. McClatchy High School Ryan Lillis Protestors approach C.K. McClatchy High School Friday Ryan Lillis 1 of 3 i 
By Ryan Lillis 
About 500 people protesting the inauguration of Donald Trump as president converged on the state Capitol Friday after marching along various routes through Sacramento. 
The march was largely peaceful, with police controlling traffic. Disability rights activist and former Sacramento mayoral candidate Russell Rawlings was among the speakers. He noted that Sacramento is a Sanctuary City, and that Trump has threatened to strip such cities of federal support. 
“We’re going to have a lot of work ahead of us,” he said. “We need to build the resistance now.” 
Four groups of marchers came together at the Capitol after starting from points in Oak Park, Land Park, West Sacramento and north Sacramento. 
One group, numbering about 100 people, started marching at Sacramento City College. About 1 p.m. Friday, they passed C.K. McClatchy High School with chants of “Join us, Join us.” 
About two dozen students walked out of the school and joined the march toward the Capitol. 
School district officials said there have been no reports of students leaving the McClatchy High School campus. “The population has been stable during the day,” said Maria Lopez, Sacramento City Unified spokeswoman. 
But McClatchy teacher Lori Jablonski said that about 25 students joined the protesters. 
“We ran to the windows when we heard the rally folks come by,” she said. “Most of my students had no idea this was happening.” 
Students also joined the march from Sacramento Charter High School in Oak Park. 
Marchers held signs declaring “Not my President,’ and Stand up, fight back.” 
Traffic was backed up on Freeport, a major thoroughfare, as marchers paraded down the middle of the street. Two motorcycle officers rode in front of them and several patrol cars followed.
